He later studied law at the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, and was admitted to the bar in 1767. He also acquired a vast library of books, which would later influence his thinking and writings.


Political Career

In 1775, Jefferson became a delegate to the Virginia legislature, where he championed colonial rights. Presidency

Jefferson was elected President in 1800 on a platform of limited government and agrarian democracy. His presidency saw the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, which doubled the size of the nation. His advocacy for the exploration of the Western territories led to the Lewis and Clark Expedition.


Later Life

After his presidency, Jefferson returned to his beloved Monticello, where he continued his scholarly pursuits. He also engaged in political battles, supporting the embargo against Britain and France and opposing the formation of political parties.


Jefferson's life was a tapestry of intellectual pursuits and public service. His ideas about government, democracy, and individual rights continue to resonate today.

He also supported the Lewis and Clark Expedition (1804-1806) to explore these newly acquired lands.
